segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: It's Friday, the 19th of January, 2024.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: The last word in podcasting news.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_3
segments.body: This is the Podnews Weekly Review with James Cridland and Sam Sethi.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: I'm James Cridland, the editor of Podnews.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: And I'm Sam Sethi, the CEO of True Funds.

segments.body: In the chapters today, welcome to the number one weekly podcast of all time, According to Good Pods.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_3

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_3

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_3
segments.body: Today, I'm going to be talking about advertising and my ongoing issue around age and ageism in the industry.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: He will.

segments.body: This podcast is sponsored by Buzzsprout.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: Podcast hosting made easy with powerful tools, free learning materials and remarkable customer support.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_3

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Okay, James, let's kick this off.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Now you had a report in Podnews Daily that podcast ads need to be funnier from Signal Hill.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: Well, apparently people, podcast consumers, people who listen to podcasts, expect and would like to hear podcasts that are funny or entertaining.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: And according to the data, what they're actually getting is podcasts that communicate features, benefits of products and services.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So not quite as exciting.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: Now, what I would say about this is that the numbers are quite close to one another.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So 71% of people say that they want funny podcasts.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: 61% of people say that they want podcasts, podcast ads, which communicate features and benefits.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So actually, there's not much difference in it, and there's not much difference in what people are actually hearing.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: 78% of people say that they're hearing the boring ads.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: 72% of people say that they're hearing entertaining ads.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So perhaps it's not quite as bad as they seem, but there's certainly a small disconnect, I guess, is what the data is showing.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: I do remember back in the late 80s, early 90s in the UK, ads became super funny, and they became very memorable because they were super funny.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: People would regale the stories of them.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: And then we went through a phase with ads in the UK where they were songs.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Do the shake and vac.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_4
segments.body: Beef grills and lamb grills.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_4
segments.body: More sizzlers from the Bird's Eye Steakhouse.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: And I remember going to a concert and they had this comedian at the beginning who came up on stage I think there was about 50, 000 people in the audience.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: And he did all the songs of adverts as his act.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: And everyone in the audience remembered every word of every advert because it was a song.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: And I just wonder, maybe that's what we need to do.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Maybe instead of making them funny, make them songs.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: I don't know.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Maybe that's the way forward.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: They were a double glazing company, and they had these awful songs that used to run over, and over, and over again.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: I mean, similarly, there was an ad, which was a very futuristic ad, I seem to remember, for a product called Ready Brek, which was a porridge, warm porridge breakfast cereal.

segments.body: Ready Brek, with lashings of hot milk to soak up those natural oats, malt and vitamins, all goodness and nothing wasted.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_4

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: Yeah, yeah, made him look radioactive.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.body: Perhaps what people are really asking for is ads that are a little bit different, perhaps.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: That's what, you know, one might guess.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Its revenues were at $19 million, up 37% quarter and quarter and up 5% on the year.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Downloads for the quarter are also only down a small amount,.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: 75% in spite of the Apple apocalypse of the auto download changes.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: James, it all sounds amazing.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Well done, Audio Boom.

segments.body: Well, it kind of all does sound amazing.

segments.body: I have been saying for quite some time that there is a difference between the US and the UK in terms of the podcast market.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: They're still not making a profit, I should say.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: But nevertheless, it seems to be quite splendid in terms of the numbers.

segments.body: I was most interested at that total downloads number.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: Because for the quarter, we have seen a lot of people who have been posting 15% down, 20% down.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: In this particular case, downloads for the quarter are only down 0.75%, which is virtually nothing.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So I think that there's probably is some good news there.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Yes, Stuart Last, the CEO of Audioboom, said the business is returning to growth mode, which is great, and it's true.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: He also said that there was a sharp increase in the number of ad slots we created per episode, with a subsequent one billion ad impressions being made available for sale to our customers in October.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: So I sort of had a look around, and when you look at the share price chart, it goes back to, let's say, March, 2023.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: It's currently, it went all the way down quite significantly by October 2023 to below 150.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: It's bounced back up to 300, roughly.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: So it's still half of the value that it was back in March 2023.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: But what made it even more scary is when I looked further back to January 2022 and the share price was at 2, 250.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: It's 10x less than January 2022.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: They really did have what I'd call a black run ski drop in terms of their share price.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: So it's good to see them returning.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: I do say that 2023 now should be just renamed the Podcast Apocalypse and the Big Bree Set because it seems like everyone's had a problem.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: Or the Podcast Winter, as Adam and Dave are calling it, which I do quite like.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: And I think you're right to highlight the number of show, the number of ads which they are selling into shows has gone up.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: They post a thing called the equivalent CPM.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So that's their average revenue per 1000 downloads.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: And that is up 59% on quarter 3 23.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So up from $37 to $58.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: So that can't just be done by yield management, by working out how much money you have, how much money you're going to charge for an ad.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: It is also just purely the amount of ads that you cram into a show.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: And I wonder necessarily whether or not that means that there's going to be even more ads in shows in the future.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_2
segments.body: Have they passed the radio 15-minute ads per hour?

segments.body: They haven't, but one thing that they do say is Audio Boom now creates more than eight advertising slots per episode download.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
segments.body: Now, that doesn't necessarily mean that they fill them.

segments.body: And in fact, I had somebody asking to advertise in this very show, and they said, we want to buy a pre-roll, a 30-second pre-roll.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_1
